div.p: JEAN ARMAN DU PLESSIS, Duke of RICHELIEU, and PEERE of FRANCE: His LIFE, &c.
Set forth By GABRIEL DVGRES.
LONDON, Printed by THO: FAWCET, for the Author. 1643.

div.head: A SHORT, AND EXACT Narration of the most remarkeable things, done and spoken by that Grand Polititian of France Iean Arman du Plessis, Cardinall of RICHELIEU.
div.p:
I Write here the Life of a Man, which hath been as much admired, envied, loved, and hated as one, that ever France brought forth. The best, and rarest wits admired the vast capacity of his transcendent mind. Some others, that aspired as high as he, but wanted his reach, envied him. They that could not endure the prosperity, greatnesse,
and flourishing estate either of the King, or of the Kingdome of France, hated him, but they, that rejoyced at the King, or Kingdomes welfare, loved him. I feare, least as an unskilfull limner doth injury very much a handsome, and compleat face with the drawing of it: I likewise blemish the lustre of the actions of that most eminent Polititian, and true Patriot, with my ruffe pen. I know, that it is with Polititians as with lovers: none can conceive, or expresse the passions of a lover, but he that hath been in love himselfe. Neither can one imagine, apprehend, or lay open the subtilties, plots, inventions, and tricks of a Polititian, that never was employed in any State businesses. But on the other side, the greatest piece of policy being to hide it: I hope to be easily excused, if I doe take only upon me to write the most eminent Cardinall his birth, life, and actions, without searching any further into his wayes, then the outward deeds,
and effects can afford us. It were a meet folly to undertake to set forth a thing, which he hath alwayes kept close, and private to himselfe. I take him to have farre exceeded Machiavel in his policy, who made the world acquainted with it. Many became good Theorists with reading his books, but few good practitioners. Policy once knowne is no more policy. They that follow the common road of it, shall be soone met withall. It is the head-piece that must be a true Polititians book. A quarter of an houre of our Red hats study hath many times overthrowne the designes, projected and concluded by a long consultation of the grave Spanish Councell.

None can taxe me of adulation in writing the Cardinals life, hee being dead, and the King his good master likewise: and in a time, in which most of them, that were of his fide, are persecuted in France. I can hope for no preferment by writing of it, but I will
render testimony unto the truth as farre as I know it: and I will honour that brave mans memory; they that are well-wishers unto the Crowne of France shall build him a monument in their owne hearts. That those things I write of the Cardinall may find more credit with the reader: I will intreat him to know, that there are but few in England, that know, or can write more things of him according to the truth, than I can doe. I was borne but ten leagues from his owne native place: I lived at severall times in Lodun a place but 3 leagues distant from Richelieu. They that have knowne the Queen-Mothers Court in the beginning of the Cardinals rising, knew likewise Messieurs les Botrus born in the City of Angiers which got into the Queenes favour at the same time: did continue in it as long as the Cardinall: were promoted to the Kings service in the time of the Cardinals promotion: and to the wonder of all men,
carried their cups so even, that in the midst of all troubles, and of all the plots and conspiracies wrought by the Queens favorites, and others against the Cardinall, they were never found tardie, were maintained in their honours, and lived in favour with the King, and Cardinall both. I spare telling what relation I have to them: This onely I will say, that my Father was borne likewise in Angiers, and that his younger brother lived in the Kings Court with them. This will suffice to make the reader think that it is probable I may know sufficiently of the Cardinall to write his life. The occasions I had these late yeeres to be with some French Lords, which were even displeased at his favour, and government, made me know many things more at large: for, if any thing could have been spoken against the Cardinall, it was not kept private in their houses. But, to speak true; I never heard the Lords themselves speak any evill
word of him, as they were men of great understanding, they did esteem highly of his rare parts. The Cardinall was borne in the yeere 1585 in the ancient Castle of Richelieu three leagues distant from the city of Lodun, upon the borders of the Provinces of Poictou, and Tourraine. His Pedigree is derived from William du Plessis, who lived under the reigne of Phil. Aug. Anno CLXXIX, unto William succeeded Peter second of the name, William the third of the name, Peter the fourth, William the fifth, Peter the sixth, Savage the seventh, Francis first of the name, the 8. in whose time the house of Richelieu entred into that of Du plessis, Francis the second, the ninth, Francis the third, the tenth, Francis the fourth, the eleventh, Father to Iean Arman du Plessis Cardinall, Duke, and Peere of France, &c. One of our Historians writeth that Francis Du Plessis, second of the name, was married unto Guyonne de la val, which was a kin
to the house of Bourlon. Our French History maketh mention of the valour, and of the warlike exploits of many of that house, and amongst all the rest, of William the first of it, who went into the Holy Land with Philip August. A house in Paris bearing the name of a family is none of the least marks of its antiquity, and noblenesse. Many English families enjoy the same honour in London. As Arundels House, Essex House, Suffolke House, Southampton House, Northampton House, &c. L'hostel de Richelieu hath been very famous in Paris, these many yeetes; to the greater glory of the family of Richelieu, the Cardinall gave the name of it to one of the gates of the City of Paris, when he did enlarge a part of St. Honorius Suburb. The Palace called, Le Palais Cardinal, in St. Honorius Street, is likewise called Richelieus Palace. Our Cardinall did put France into a maze in his youth. For, his quick, and subtile wit,
his judgement ripe afore the wonted time, and the proofes hee gave of his rare parts in the Schooles of humane learning, shewing himselfe a most eloquent Rhetorician, and a subtile, and sound Philosopher made the world think that there was something in him, which did savour more of the Angelicall, than of the humane nature. All these things being done by him under the age of eighteen. Hee studyed Divinity in the famous, and ancient faculty of Sorbonne to the wonder of the most learned Doctors of it, which admired the solidity of his reasons, and the subtility of arguments, which passed many times their solutions, and answers. He went out Doctor in that Colledge; Alphonse the Bishop of Lucon his brother gave his Bishoprick over to him, and betooke himselfe to a Carthusian Cloister, Iean du Plessis being not capable of that charge by the Canons of the Church of Rome, for want of age, Paul
the fift dispensed with him by reason of his deserts, and learning. Returned to Paris from Rome, he went to give humble thanks to Henry the fourth, and to kisse his Majesties hand, who received him most favourably, and told him that this was the first dignity the Church had bestowed upon him; but his merits would obtaine the greatest shee could conferre upon him. They that have read our French History know of the conference held in Lodun 1616, where the greatest Princes, and Nobles met after the damnable murther, and ever bleeding death of the most renowned, and never to bee so gotten Henry the fourth: to consult about the Kingdomes affaires. The Cardinall got there acquaintance with the best and chiefest Courtiers. A very neere kinswoman of his being one of the Queen-Mothers Ladies of Honour, commended him to her Mistresse, who after the knowledge of his extraordinary parts admitted him
into her Court, and Councell. Some have thought it dishonourable to the Cardinall that a woman should bee the first that introducted him into the Queens Court. It is not so. Courtiers are all like those of the Church of Rome, they need one Saint, or another to bring them into the presence, and favour of their Soveraigne. If it be a he, or a she Saint, it mattereth not. Jean du Plessis Bishop of Lucon, was not long after nominated Embassadour in extraordinary to the King of Spaine to treat betweene him, and the Duke of Savoye. But the Queene seeing that hee could doe better service at home, made him the Kings first Secretary. His facility in the expedition of most important, and difficult affayres, his judgement in his Counsels, his politenesse in his conversation, his eloquence in his discourses, his subtility in his replies, his Rhetorick, and elegancy in his writings, and diligence in dispatching businesses
made the world sufficiently know what hee was. The Marquesse of Ancre an Italian borne, husband to the Queenes Foster sister, played his pranks in France about that time, and did domineere over all the Princes, Nobles, and over all the whole Kingdome of France. Even so much that hee came to that height of pride, and scorne of the Councell of State, that hee was wonted to tell them that hee did not aske them counsell of what hee was to doe, but onely of what they called formes of proceeding. Hee became at last intollerable to the King himselfe, who commanded Mr. De Vitry Captain of his Guards to pistoll him, which hee did performe according to the charge he had. Here is a remarkable thing of our Bishop; that, although he was the first Secretary of State during the base government, or rather tiranny of the Marquesse, yet hee did carry himselfe so discreetly, and so wisely, that hee
kept the Kings favour still. Monsieur de Luynes his Majesties only Favorite, assured the King, that Messire Iean du Plessis Bishop of Lucon had served him well, even during the Marquesse of Anchor his time, who was pistolled, as wee have told. The Queen somewhat sensible of his death retired her selfe to Blois. Our Bishop had leave given him to waite upon her thither. Hee stayed there not much above a moneth. For, his envious perswaded the King that hee was a bad Counsellour to Her Majesty. Hee went thence to his Priorie of Caussay, where he made a booke called The Christian Doctrine; Envie followed him so farre, and got him a remoove from thence to Avignon, in which Henry Lord of Richelieu, and Monsieur Du Pont his Brother in Law were comprehended. His Brothers death was the the greatest unhappinesse hee had there. The Duke of Espernon did convey the Queen-Mother out of the Castle of
Blois to Loches, and from thence to Angoulesme. Many did say, and more did think that the Bishop of Lucon was the projector of that designe. Yet notwithstanding all this, the Duke of Luynes the Kings Grand Favorite sent him a letter to desire him to returne to the Queene: The King himselfe wrote with his owne hand these following words. I desire you to believe that the things above written are according to my will; and that you cannot please me better, than if you doe according to them. Some thought the reason, why the King sent for him back againe out of Avignon, was because hee feared least hee should passe over either into Savoye, or into Italy: for, he had sufficient proofes of his working braines; and some others, did conceive, that the King being desirous to be reconciled with his Mother, thought no man so able, or fit to work his reconciliation as the Bishop was. Who, took his journey towards
the Queene presently after the receit of that letter: he was arrested betweene Valentia, and Vienna, by the Captaine of the Marquesse of Alincour his Guards, but soone after set at liberty by the Marquesse himselfe after a complementall excuse. The Queene having set her hand to the agreement betweene his Majesty and hers: sent the Bishop of Lucon with them to the King; They were both favourably received. The King told the Bishop, that he thought himselfe bound to acknowledge his good service. By that agreement the government of Angiers, Pont de ce, and Chinon, was given to the Queene. The King, and the Queene were not long after up in armes one against the other. Le Pont de cé stood against the King, some few unfortunate, and unwise men were killed of both sides. The King took Le Pont de cé, new agreements were drawne by his Councell, and sent to Her Majesty by Monsieur de Crequy; She signed
them, and returned them to the King by the Cardinall de Sourdis, and the Bishop of Lucon. Many have thought that these bickerings between the King, and His Mother were but counterfeited, and that it was but a trick to raise men to fall upon the Protestants before they could make a considerable party to resist the Kings forces. I cannot affirme it for truth. I will only say that the Warres against the reformed in France begun not long after. (Would to God the Kings, and the Parliaments forces would now joyne together to fall upon the Irish Rebells in case they could agree together, and make a true, blessed, and happy Peace in England.) 1622 our Bishop of Lucon was made Cardinall of Richelieu. 1624 He was chosen to bee the first Minister of State, at Campiegne. 1626 The Cardinall perswaded the King to make sure of the Duke of Vendosme, and of the Grand-prior his naturall brothers. To call the States
to Nauntes, where the Earle of Chalais master of the Kings Warderope was beheaded in the month of August in the same yeare. It hath been said openly enough in France that their plot was to put the King into a Cloister, that hee might apply himselfe the better to his devotions without any disturbance by the care of his Kingdome. And so Monsieur the Duke of Orleans his brother was to be set in the Throne, and many of the Nobles were to share either the Kingdomes parts, or, the dignities amongst themselves. How true it is, I know not. But, if it was so, the Cardinall did the King no small service in the discoverie of the plot. Some thought otherwise of it: for it was said in France, that there was nothing intended against the Kings person, but that all their aime was at the Cardinall himselfe: who was a great eye-sore unto them. He was in 1627 made Admirall of France; the Duke of Montmorency resigned
his place unto him, for which the King gave him the government of Languedoc the Duke did not like of that exchange as it appeared afterwards. 1628 The Cardinall was made Generall of the Kings forces against that famous, and renowned City of Rochell; before which the King had spent five moneths already, and three Kings had besieged it afore him. He did more with his wit, and policy, than all the Kings forces could doe by their strength. For, he bridled the Sea; and to the wonder of all the world, built a banke to stop the passages of those Ships that would have been sent out of the City to fetch in reliefe: and to keep any other from sailing into it. Rochell was at last forced to yeeld unto the King after a tedious famin, who entred into it on all-Holy-tide 1628. Thus a brave, and well fortified City, which stood afore against two, or, three Kings, and which was thought impregnable: was taken by the device,
and subtility of the Cardinall. I will relate here some French verses made by some of the Kings forces, two, or three moneths afore the surrendring of it.

He knew that it could not bee taken but by famine, he wrought all the means conducing to that effect. The victuals borrowed out of it for the English Navy a going into the Isle of Ré, was no small preparation unto it. For, they were never payd againe, as they say. I cannot think that the good Duke of Buckingham had so base a designe, as to be accessary to the ruine of such a place, and of men, that professed the Religion, he professed himselfe. But such was perhaps his bad fortune to be ill thought of by some of the English, and by all French Protestants. The twentieth of
August 1629, the Cardinall entred into Montaulban, and was royally entertained by the Citizens, which had chosen him for their Governour. They used that honest policy, seeing that there was no possibility that they could withstand alone, all the Kings army, and in a manner whole France it selfe. They had prepared a rich Canopy for his more honourable reception: he thanked them saying, That it was fitter for a King than for him. Our Cardinall was chosen that same yeere Generall of the Kings forces in Piedmont. When he was at Suse, the Queen-Mother began to be jealous of his prosperous successe, and endeavoured to lay an aspersion upon his fidelity: yet the King well perswaded of his Lovalty, gave no credit to her words. She consulted with Mr. de Marillac then Lord-Keeper of the Great Seale in France, how she might rid her selfe of the Cardinall: but their consultation proved very unsuccessefull
to both: for, Mr. de Marillac lost his bead-piece; and the Queen went to take the fresh ayre into Bruxels. Yet notwithstanding all this: the Cardinall asked her before the King, if he had committed any thing against his Majesty: and she answered, no. Hee wrote her this Letter,

body.p:
I Know how my enemies, or rather the enemies of the State not contented to have discredited me unto your Majesty; endeavour besides to bring my abode neer the King, into suspition: as if I came only neer him to remoove him from. You and to divide what God, and nature have joyned, I hope in the divine bounty that their malice will be knowne: that my comportments will hee shortly justified; and that my innocency shall triumph over calumnie. It is not MADAM, but, that I count my selfe unfortunate in that I cease
from pleasing your Majesty: and, but life is odious to me in the state I am, deprived of the honour of your favour, and of that esteeme, which I loved farre more than the greatnesse of the earth: as I hold it from your liberall hand, I doe likewise bring it, and prostrate it at your feet. Excuse MADAM your owne work, and your creature. All that shall proceed from your Royall humour, shall be received by me without murmuring, and followed with a thousand blessings. But MADAM, spare I beseech you (through that piety, which is naturall unto you) the purple of the Church wherewith you have cloathed me; which will loose its splendour and lustre, if your Majesty imprinteth in it so black a spot. What likely-hood, that the most obliged man were the most ingratefull; and that my conscience, my interests, and my first inclination binding me to your service, I should have separated my selfe from it, through the onely advantage of gaining
unto my selfe the name of traytour unto my best, and greatest QUEEN of the world?

That well considered MADAM, should absolve me from crime, and from suspition before the Tribunall of your Majesty: which hath almost condemned me without bearing me. But I appeale not from it, because I am infinitely well resigned unto all your will, I subscribe unto my disaster, and I will not contend with my Soveraign Mistresse, nor aske her reason of what she hath done, neither doe I think to fortifie my selfe with the support of my Master, nor with his Officers, nor with the remembrance of my former services, against the course of your indignation: the very thoughts of it would be guilty; and farre from the inclination which I have alwayes showed in seeking for glory in Loyalty, and for security in the only innocency. I desire much lesse to draw a miserable fortune in France, or to carry it into Rome, to see therein more lamentable ruines than mine
owne. It would be tedious unto me to be in any place from which your Majesty should be absent and without the leave to see you, I have none else but to dye. But, I could wish for my reputation sake, and for the ranke I have in the house of God, that it were after my innocency was knowne: and (if it is not too much audacity in me) after the recovery of your favour. If this happeneth unto me, I will grieve no more to depart from Court; nay, from the very world. I dye howsoever a thousand times a day, since your Majesty maketh as if you did believe that I am no more my selfe. That is to say,

closer.signed:
The most humble, most faithfull,
and most obedient servant
ARMAN, Cardinall
de RICHILIEU.

div.p:
THe Princesse of Conty, the Duke of Guise, the Dutchesse of Elbeuf, Madam de Fargis, Mr. de Marillac aforenamed, and his brother, Monsieur de Belle-garde, Mr. de Bassompierre, & Mr. Vautier the Queens Physitian have been thought to have all conspired together the Cardinals ruine. But, they could never undermine him; for hee was grounded upon the rock. As he was constant in his faithfull service to the King: so did his Majesty likewise never alter, or diminish his favour to him: but he did rather encrease it from time to time, and so continued it to the Cardinals death and his not surviving long after him, might happily cause many one to think, that the griefe he tooke for the losse of so constant a Subject, did advance his dayes. 1632 the Duke of Orleans took up armes against his brother, and involved in the broyles the ever-renowned Duke of Montmorency, but unfortunate, and overseene in this onely businesse:
who being wounded and taken prisoner at Chastelnau, d'Array, by the Marshall of Schomberg then Generall of the Kings forces: was carried to Tolouse, where being only 34 yeeres old he lost his head upon a Scaffold. All the Court, nay whole France did grieve for the miserable death of so compleat, and so Noble a Duke. And so much the more, because so ancient, and so faithfull a race to the Crowne of France did perish, and dye in him. He being the first man of his Progenie, that had ever committed any fault against any King of France, did deserve pardon. France would have bin very thankfull to the Cardinall for the procuring, and to the King for granting of it. But, publike good cannot many times consist with private good. It is often needfull that men of greatest births, and parts suffer punishment for their faults, to the example, and terrour of those that are either of an equall, or of an inferiour rank with them.

I leave of here tracing the Cardinals life yeere after yeere, and writing of his dignities. For, I can say in few words, that ever from 1631 untill his death, he was the only man, upon whom the King reposed the trust of his whole Kingdom, and of the affaires out of the Kingdom: and who was the maine instrument of his Majesties will. Many indiscreet, and ignorant persons have wrongfully taxed our deceased King for want of wit, imagining themselves that the King did let the Cardinall rule, because hee himselfe was not able to governe. They wanted wit, and knowledge in their censure. The greatest part of a Princely wisdome being to chuse wise, understanding, and faithfull States-men: and to be able to discerne between them that are truly affected to the good of his Crowne: and them, that seek onely their owne ends, and which put him upon designes, destructives to himselfe, and to his Kingdome. Judicious, and
wise men shall ever think, and beleeve, that Lewis the thirteenth was of a singular, and rare judgement, and wisdome. Since, he was able to judge, and chuse among the rest, one that went farre beyond any man of our age, in wit, understanding, Judgement, and Loyalty to his King, and Kingdome. I will speak a bold word. The antiquity had never any that exceeded him: few, or none, that could be paralleld with him. Many have been grand Polititians, as Elius Sejanus, and such like: enjoyed great dignities, and were in great favour with their Soveraigns. Fortune did smile upon them for a while: she raised, and extolled them to the height of favour, and then she brought them to the lowest of the disgrace, and dishonour. Most of them dyed an unnaturall death either by poyson, by the sword, or by the hangman. It is thought that Mr. de Luynes the Cardinals predecessour was poysoned. It is knowne in England, that the
Duke of Buckingham was stabbed with a knife by Felton. I have seen my selfe my Lord Wentworth Viceroy of Ireland to loose his head upon a Scaffold on Tower hill 1641. So miserable is the condition of most Favorites. For, some things they undertake, prove well to their advantage, and glory: and some others very ill, and disadvantageous both to them, and to their Kings. But the Cardinall was ever fortunate from the first minute of his favour to the last moment of his life. The Kings favour did continue, or rather increase to his very death. Let envie it selfe speake, or name that one thing, hee undertooke, that ever proved to his shame, to the disadvantage either of his King, or of his Kingdome. His enemies gave bad constructions to his designes: but the events of them shewed him faithfull to the Crowne of France. When was the name of the French more glorious, than in his time? When did any King
get more victories, and conquered more places in so short a time, than Lewis the thirteenth did through his Counsels? I doe not say that the King took the Cardinals counsell without using his owne discretion: but, that knowing him the wisest, and most faithfull of all his Counsellours, he gave more credit to his counsell than to any bodies else. Many one have thought that the Cardinall did rather work by the Kings direction, than the King by his counsels; and that the King had given over to him the managing of his affaires upon a meer policy. So did a gentleman of great rank, and one of the middle Temple tell me: who having occasion to speak with his Majesty, was entertained by him with as much courtesie as any one could be entertained: The Cardinall came then to the King, which commended the gentleman to him. His Eminency gave him but a nod; but the businesse was performed according to the gentlemans expectation.
We are often deceived, when wee thinke that Favorites work all of themselves. They are but instruments of their Masters will. If the things they doe, be pleasing to the people, they have their good words, if displeasing, all the venome, and anger is vomited against the poore favorites. The King is safe from their hatred. They say, that he is the best natured Prince, and the most debonnaire King, if it were not for his base, and wicked favorite. It is so many times, I confesse it: but yet; favorites are too often thought to bee the givers of counsels, and contrivers of designes, when they are but the executors of them. Kings, and other Soveraignes conceive many times great matters, and frame grand designes within themselves: They lye in their heads, untill they be fit, and ready to bee brought forth: The favorite must doe the office of a Midwife to give them entrance into the world. For, Princes are like Jove, their bearing
place is the head. It is seldome seene that a favorite endeavoureth to crosse the disposition, or to alter the naturall inclination of his Master: he doth rather observe it, and sympathize with it as much as hee can. Cicero giveth the character of an observing favorite in these words. Loquitur ad voluntatem, assentatur, assidet, admiratur. So that: if the Princes nature is good, hee dareth not counsell him any bad thing: if bad, he seldome goeth about to amend it. A good nature may (I deny it not) be corrupted by bad counsels, and more especially if they doe appeare in the shape of good. An easie, and a debonnaire one may easily. bee wrought upon. Evill words corrupt good manners. Kings believe many lies, because they are presented unto them cloathed like truths: and they doe often commit evill, when their Councell perswadeth them that they doe good.

Let us speak now of some of the Cardinals
rarest parts, and that pro modulo nostro, according to our possibility: For, to undertake to comprehend them all, were to doe as if one did goe about to put all the water of the Thames in a Cockle-shell. To presume to describe them fully, and as they were. It would be as if a picture-drawer would presume to animate his draughts: or rather as if he should thinke that the picture he hath drawne were equall with the live body. when it is but a meer shadow of it: so likewise, whatsoever (not I only) but also any man else can say of the Cardinals brave parts, it will bee but an imperfect draught of his excellent perfections.

Every action of his life speaketh him wise: nay, his whole life (since hee had the use of reason) was but a continued wisdome. Rome, which was in former ages the dwelling place of wise men, and the sea it selfe of wisdome, and is now (to give every man their
due) the rendez-vouz and receptacle of many wise, and excellent wits: did take him for a young Apollo when hee went thither to be made Bishop by Gregory the 15. For: every sentence hee spoke was an oracle. Hee made the depth of his wisdome knowne unto the said Gregory, but under the secret of confession. And the Pope said then that hee would overturn the whole world. He altered some yeeres after, the face of the affaires of France: and almost of all Europe.

The wisdome of a man is knowne in his words, and in his deeds: wee shall speak of his deeds, when wee come to discourse of his policie. As for his words, we will relate some of his wise sayings: but wee will leave of many, because they might perhaps distaste some that should read them.

The old Latin Proverb saith, that, Vir sapit qui paeuca loquitur. A man is wise that sayeth but little. Wee have
likewise two old Proverbs in French to this purpose. Parlez peu; parlez bien. Parlez rien, ou parlez bien. The first is in English. Speak little, speak well: and the second is: speak nothing, or speak well: If every man did observe that rule punctually, and followed those Proverbs exactly, it was the Cardinall. For, except in publike meetings, and when State-businesses were in agitation, he spoke very little, or nothing at all: we said afore, that when the King himselfe did speak to him in the behalfe of an English Gentleman, hee nodded only unto the Gentleman and gave him never a word.

The Poet said, that Semel in anno ridet Apollo. Our French Apollo did hardly laugh once in two yeeres in the sense that the Poet speaketh it. Hee was not of a frowning Countenance, though he was grave: his gravity was not severe, but accompanied many times with smiles.

p.hi: Here follow some of his Sentences.

div.p: 1. It is only for great minds to goe on in their designes though their actions be censured, and controlled.
2. The best book of a States-man, is Experience: that only book will make him sooner, and more learned, than all the Politicks in the world.
3 The borders of Kings Empires are measured by their strength. I doe not like of this sentence.
4. Private faults in States-men, may be pardoned, but they, by which the publick is offended, can, and must never be excused.
5. To neglect the punishment of great crimes is still to permit, and to give an encouragement for the committing of greater.
6. To punish men of a low condition, and let the great ones be unpunished, is to kill little Snakes, and to let great Dragons live.
7. That businesses or imployments make man.

8. He said that he approved not of that saying of Tacitus. Fortunae saevienti submittendus animus. The heart must yeeld unto the cruelty of fortune. But said, on the contrary, that the more fierce, and cruell fortune is, the greater must a wise mans courage be, and the more stiffely hee must stand against her. Hee hath put that saying of his, in practise during many yeeres; for, the greater was the rage of his great enemies, the more constant he was in his wayes: and went on the more couragiously in the designes he had projected for the good of the King, and of the Kingdome of France.
9. That a States-man must seek for glory in his fidelity, and for security in his innocency.
10. That absence is the best safegard for one that hath offended his Prince.

11. That men must not be rash, and precipitated in their counsels; when the
matter concerneth the good of the Prince, and of the Kingdome: but, when the resolution is taken upon a mature deliberation, to be slow in the execution is to shew a kind of unwillingnesse: and to incurre the danger of suspition.
12. That it is a generous kind of vengeance, to let our enemies know that we can avenge our selves of the injuries they have done us, and yet, pardon them.
13. That the Favorites center must be the good of his King, and of his Kingdomes: all his designes must be as the lines drawne from it, which must end into it.

14. He said that although the credit, favour, and greatnesse of accusers useth to cast men accused into despaire: yet a faithfull States-man must bee the more resolute, the greater his accusers are, and the more constant in his service: because it will adde to his glory (when hee hath cleered himselfe) that
he hath withstood the false accusations of so potent enemies.

15. That a States-man that deserteth the service of his King, and Kingdom by reason of the many oppositions, and difficulties hee meeteth in his way: is no better then a traytour, that betrayeth his King, and his Kingdome: and giveth them both in prey to their enemies.

16. That the greatest strength of a King, and of a Kingdome consisteth in reputation. For, if their enemies thinke them strong and couragious, they dare not make any attempt against them: and their neighbours will seek to have a league with them. If they goe about Conquering, or about regaining any thing, that was formerly lost: Their very name, and fame shall conquer, and regaine it.

17. When some of his Friends did tell him, that he had many enemies, and that hee was in great danger of his life.
He answered thus. Satis est si hoc habemus ne quis nobis malè facere possit. It is enough (said he) if we have wherewithall to keep any body from offending us. If hee meaned by these words his guards, or the Kings favour I know not; perhaps he meaned them both.
18. That we must never hazard with losse, that, which wee can obtaine with security.
19. That one, that is in favour cannot free himselfe from envy, but by loosing, or leaving that favour, which is the cause of envie.
20. That a man, that endeavoureth to mend those things, that are corrupted in the States, shall never want dangers: because the remedy must bee violent against corruption: and violence is dangerous.

21. That a Prince desirous to govern his States with justice and to keep the love of his Subjects, ought not to establish by force that which he may obtain
by faire meanes, neither to aske by arms what is due unto reason.

22. That people feele more the present time, than they feare the time to come: and that they complaine for a small matter that they contribute for their defence, and preservation: and thinke not that their totall ruine is prevented by that meanes. That they know not how to chuse the lesser evill: as an (expert Pilot doth) which seeing his ship tossed by the winds, and in danger of a ship-wrack, casteth into the Sea a part of his fraught to save the rest, and thinketh not to loose what hee giveth willingly for the preservation of his life.
The Cardinall used these words to shew, that it was lawfull for him to leavie mony of the people for the maintaining of his necessary warres.

23 That he approved not of the Iesuites opinion, which is, that faith must not be kept with hereticks. For, said he, if wee ought not to keep it, wee ought
much lesse to give it them.

24. When some of the Protestants back-friends told him that it were better to have but one Religion in France: because the diversity of Religion is apt to cause dissentions, he answered them in these words. Maneat concordia benenevolentiae inter sententiâ discordes. Let them that differ in opinion, agree in mutuall love.

25. That publick services must bee rewarded by publick charges, and not with money; because the recompence must be knowne for the encouragement of others: and must last long, that it may be remembred the longer.
26. That it is better to prevent crimes, than to punish them: and that it is to doe a favour unto them, that intended to doe evill, to take away from them the power of doing it.
27. That patience must atchieve, what strength cannot end.

28 That the Science of vanquishing
consisteth in making good use of a victory.
29. That precepts of Policie may be easily put in writing, but hardly in practise.
30. That men attribute many times to a deficiencie of wisdome, that, which is a meer want of fortune.
31. That it is better to confute, and convince our accusers, and enviers by our vertues, and good deeds, than by words of purgation.

32. That a man, that thinketh himselfe learned and wise enough, is an ignoramus, and a foole. And therefore though he was so litterate, and so understanding a man, he did neglect no occasion of benefiting himselfe either in learning, or in wisdom. To that effect he conversed with learned men as much as his grand imployments could permit him. Nay, hee stole many houres from his naturall rest to heare severall books of learning, and especially of ancient
histories read unto him by some young, and learned Student. Mr. Bodin a young Sorbonist, now beneficiate in Paris was one of the last. The grave L'Escot, now Bishop of Chartres did wish him, and commend him unto the Cardinall, which did benefit himselfe mightily by hearing those books read unto him: For; then he framed, and builded his designes upon the actions of the ancient, not that hee imitated, or followed them strictly, for he went farre beyond them; but because, that lecture did help somewhat his mind, and memory after a painefull day of serious imployments.

33. That, as the diversity of voices maketh a perfect harmony, provided that there be a discordant concordancy: so likewise in a Kingdome, or in a Republike: The disparity of persons, of offices, and of dignities, maketh a perfect consort in case there bee an union, and an agreement amongst them. There must bee a Prince, and Subjects, great
ones and little ones, a Magistrare and a people, some to command, and some to obey. If they keep all time, and be not out of tune, the melody will be very sweet.
I conclude the discourse of his wisdome by that which Balzac said of him (though too prophanely by his leave.) That he was so wise, that God might repose the government of the whole world upon him.

Let us now speak of his Policy, which is very neere a kinne to wisdome. We cannot judge of any mans policy but by the effects: Though wee doe attribute many times unto policy those things, which are but meere fortune: and on the contrary, wee censure mens wisdome, when wee see some events which doe rather proceed from the want of fortune, then from the defect of prudence.
It is much to conceive, and to project grand designes: but it is more to bring them forth, and to execute them.
The life is in the action. What profiteth one to aime at brave ends, if he cannot tell how to find out the meanes to execute them?

The Cardinals chiefest end was to make the King of France absolute, glorious, and renowned: and his Kingdome to flourish. To obtaine it, he removed all the obstacles either at home, or abroad, that could be any hinderance to his proceedings. Hee did imagine that so long as the Protestants had strong Holds, and pledge-townes in France, the King was not absolute in his Kingdome: and therefore hee did put the King upon the Protestant warres, and perswaded him to take all the places they had, from them, it was done so. The King got the masterie. His policy was like to prove disadvantageous unto the King, and to himselfe afterwards. For, except the Protestants had been in posture of helping them; his mast er, and hee, would have been in great danger.
1632, His wisdom could not but dictate him that the strength of the Protestant party in France is the preservative of the Crowne, and Kingdom of France. But, what he did then, he did it out of policy, that he might be called no more the Cardinall Huguenot.

There were many great men, and others in France like to stirre, and to side with the Spaniards, he caused some of them to be imprisoned, and some others to bee put to death: happy were they, that could escape the bad day, and get over out of the Kingdome of France.

Hee knew that the house of Austria was a great annoyance unto the house of Bourbon, and that it kept too much light from it. Therefore he endeavoured to pull it downe piece by piece. 1631, He called the King of Swedeland into Germany to give the first stroake; he did like a very good workman, and had not death prevented his designes, that house would have been levelled with the ground afore
now. Generall Bannire did further the work pretty well, and the Swedes are a working still. The Catalonians and the Portingals have had each one a very good pull at it, they were all the Cardinals workmen, he was the Grand Enginiere. They that he thought to be inclined towards the house of Austria, and which he perceived to bee more defirous of the Spaniards prosperity, than of the French were prevented in their designes by some businesses hee gave them at home. I could enlarge my selfe upon this subject. I could shew the occasions, and reasons, which moved him to doe so. I could name some persons he imployed in that businesse. I could tell how hee dispersed, and broke the Spanish faction in a Kingdome, that shall bee namelesse. I rather grieve to think of the miseries, in which they are now than doe desire to relate the reasons, and occasions of them. And if the Cardinall were now alive, I beleeve that
he would rather seek to compose their distractions, than to further them: for, he would be contented to see the Spanish faction disinabled for helping the Spaniard. And perhaps they, that are now Counsellours of that Kingdome would rather side with France, than with Spain: or at least they would deale equally betwixt both: for, when we deale betwixt two of our friends that are at oddes amongst themselves: we shall make one of them our enemy, if hee perceiveth that we rather take part with his enemy than with him. The Pensionaries, and Intelligencers he kept abroad, cost him fifteen thousand crownes a week. Mr. Delope a Jew, or a Portingall was the man, that payed most of them.

There could hardly bee six men in a company but three of them were of the Cardinals spies, or Intelligencers; and many times the whole company proved all intelligencers. And yet they knew not one another, and every one of them
endeavoured to intrap the others. It was likewise so with his pensionaries: for: though hee had many in the same place, and in one Kingdome, yet hee would not have them know one another. He had two men, unto which he gave the charge of all the affaires. One was to take care of those that were within the Kingdome: and the other did onely look after forraine businesses. He imparted his designes unto them telling them, that none but they knew them, and therefore if they should ever be discovered, they were to look to themselves. Mr. de Chavigny, and Mr. de Noyers were the men. Cardinall Mazarin his successour, and during his life his collegue, and another himselfe: did concurre much with him for the good of France: for he was of one mind, and of one heart with him.

One thing I dislike much in his policie. It was his way of getting, or making of Souldiers: For, when he propounded
unto the King his Master his great designes for advancing his glory, and for the destruction of Spaine: the King asked him how he should get souldiers enough to bring these Grand Designes to execution. Being, that none are pressed in France, and that none can be forced, or compelled, except Gentlemen, which are called the Arriereban: and are onely to attend his Majesties person upon extraordinary, and most important affaires. Henry the fourth that invincible Monarch of ours, called them, and they were prepared: but Ravaillac munster of nature, and the shame of France did cut off his designes by stabbing of him. Lewis the thirteenth of late, and happy memory called them likewise when he went into Italy. The Cardinal intreated the King to take no care, and to let him alone for that: because hee had a way to get his Majesty more souldiers than be should need. To that effect, he laid many heavy taxations
upon the people, and so: the poore he made more, the more souldiers hee got. Hee knew that the breaking of trades-men was the making of souldiers. The best piece of his policie was to make no use of those Grand Polititians, Grand Contrivers, Grand Plotters, Grand Disturbers of the Peace of Europe: which men call Iesuites: First, because he knew that they were too well affected unto the Crowne of Spaine, to prove faithfull unto France: Secondly, by reason that they think to have ingrossed all the wit, and policie in the world, and so would have every body to be ruled, or governed by their Counsels, which ever proved destructives. The old Emperour of Germany did undoe himselfe and all his Empire by believing of them. It is very strange that those Omniscient Gentlemen knew not the way to Pamprou.

The Cardinall imployed much one Father Ioseph a Capucin Fryar, who
though he wore a very course garment had a very refined wit. Hee did France great service; especially in Germany: and it is thought that the Cardinall was ruled by his counsells whilst hee lived. Their enimies did set up one night at the Pasquill in Rome, these lines against them both: nay, against the Pope, and the King of France himselfe.

This I will say for his reaching policy and no more. That his mind was like a circle, which can containe any other figure, but cannot be contained by any. So likewise: he could comprehend all 〈…〉 policie, and devices of any 〈◊〉 but none was able to apprehend, or to conceive his own wisdom, and policy. La V •… , La S • se, Casal, L • rraine, 〈◊〉 , St. Honor •… . Et St. Marguerite
Islands, Th • rin, Tort •… , Pignerol, Arras, Aire, (though lost again) Cata •… , Portingal, Perpignan, & E. have selt the power of his policy. He had alwaies an equall mind in prosperity, and in adversity, exceeding not in one, & being not desicient in the other. As he was nor transported with over-joy, so likewise he was never cast down, nor dejected by griefe: using a moderation in his prosperity, and patience in his adversity; which was not because he had ever any bad successe in any of his enterprises: but, by reason that he had so many enemies, which did seek his life, and the mine of France. Though he was constant, he was not insensible: his heart was not made of Diamond, neither was it like Piadarus Cinoas his skin, which was so tuffe, and so hard, that he did dart back the arrowes that were shot against him. He was no Stoick, but his constancy was accompanied with a reasonable wisdom: for hee did grieve sometimes when there
was occasion of grieving, and he rejoyced: but yet, was no wise distempered, for, he had so great a command over his passions, that they were all at his beck, they obeyed his call: they went no farther, then reason could afford them to goe: for she was alwayes their guide, and leader.

Once onely the Cardinall broke out into passion, when the newes of Walstein's death was brought to him: for, then he did bite, and tare his hand karchief in pieces, and retired himselfe into his closet for a while. Walstein was (as almost every body knoweth) the Emperour of Germany his Generall. The Cardinals designe was (as men did conceive) to make Lewis the thirteenth Emperour of Germany, himselfe King, or at least Vicery of France: and Walstein, which was to give his souldiers unto the King of France: was promised the Dukedome of Bavaria. But, the designe being discovered, Gourden Governour of Egger
killed Walstein February the twenty sift, 1634. and foure of his Captaines, together with a Page, when they were all at dinner, and then cryed Vive l'Empereur.

He was so excellent a Rhetorician, that if truth it selfe, and all the Orators in the world had been of one side, and he of an other: yet he was able to make his opinion to be thought, and received for the best. Therefore, we must not wonder if he did ever draw men unto his side, and if his Counsels were approved with a generall applause, and followed with a generall consent: Since his mouth was the Organe of Truth it selfe (I mean in civill affaires) and that he never used his Rhetorick, but to declare truth unto men, and to make them believe, and follow it.

The assembly of the most noted, and chiefe Gentlemen of France, held in Paris about the latter end of 1626. heard many pieces of his eloquence. He perswaded them all to yeeld unto
the Kings demands as being just, and to consent unto the Articles His Majesty did propound them. The second of which was that the Protestants in France should be maintained in their ancient freedome, priviledges, and liberties.

The Earle of Chalais, which was beheaded, or rather miserably butchered in in Nauntes, hearing that Madamoiselle de Montpensier was promised unto Monsieur the Duke of Orleans. Broke into these words. Thou hast a perswading Demon O Cardinall. The Marshall of Schomberg used to tell him, that they did deferre, and yeelded much unto him: not so much because of the authority, in which the King had placed him, as for the strength of his reasons, and of his eloquence.

He stole every bodies heart through the eares, his speech was so charming that he enchanted every one. None did ever part from him unsatisfied. For he knew how to winne mens love, by a wise,
and discreet complacencie: for though hee was somewhat stately, hee was not scornefull; and though hee was of a pleasing humour, he was no flatterer. Yet many have said that they were pleasantly deceived by him, and that he was like a Camaeleon that assumeth all kinds of colours, except the white: but, it was black envie that made them speak so basely against his free, and sincere candour. For, as he never bestowed any praise upon unworthy Subjects; so likewise, he never dispraised deserving men. Deserts were alwayes rewarded, and faults punished by him, using a discreet wisdom both in his rewards, and in his punishments. Hee discerned betweene false, and true parts of men. He never took temerity for a great spirit, covetousnesse for good husbandry Impudencie for courage, prating for eloquence, stupidity for modesty, Insolencie for freedome, and in a word: he never mistook vice for Vertue, or Vertue for
vice; nor Truth for a lye. For, the light of his understanding dissipating the clouds which kept things hidden from other men, made them to appeare unto him as they were: so that he esteemed of every thing and of every one as he was indeed, and not as he was in other mens opinion: or in his owne. He honoured much the Nobility of Bloud, but he did respect farre more the Nobility of Vertue. And indeed; since all bloud is of a colour, and since it is either health, or sicknesse, that maketh a difference in mens bloud, I see no reason why we should worship, and honour so much men onely because they are Nobly descended: and why we should respect so little Vertuous, and brave minds lodged in bodies of a meane extraction. I grant, and will give the honour due unto Noble-men for their rankes sake: but I shall never Idolize a thing, that commeth by meer fortune. I will admire a Vertuous, and a Generous
soule in a Noble mans body as a rich Diamond set in gold: but I will esteem no lesse of a like Diamond, if it were set in brasse. I say that it is much to be borne Great, but it is more to become such by Vertue, and merits. The envie, which the Princes, and Noble-men of France borne unto the Cardinall because he did not let them have, and share all the offices, and dignities of France, hath occasioned me to fall into this discourse. For, they thought that great charges were intailed upon onely Great, and Noble-Houses. But the Cardinall was of another opinion. If Vertue, Deserts, and Nobility met all in one Subject, that party was sure to be the object of his favours. The Earle of Arcour, the Marquesse of Alincour, The Marshall de la Mesteraie, and the Marshall of Breze being all of Noble Families, have been honoured by him with many brave charges, and dignities, because he knew them vertuous, and deserving.
And be sides them, many others, which I name not, for, it is not my intent to make here a catalogue of them upon which hee bestoved the favours due unto their merits, and noble births. Amongst all, which were not of so Great; and of so Noble Houses, yet ascended almost to the highest dignities of France, I will name only the ever renowned Gassion, that brave, undaunted, and conragious spirit, the terrour of Spaine, the glory of Bearne, and of all France it selfe, who was imployed as a Generall by the Cardinall, and even after the Cardinals death had the Marshals staffe sent to him by the young King of France for a reward of his former services, and more especially for the great overthrow hee gave unto the Spanish Army about Rawcroy; where the most Noble, and most valiant Prince (though yet very young in yeeres, the Duke of Auguien was Generall. Gassion was like another
Marius, amongst the Romanes; who being but meanly borne, ascended by his vertue to such a point of Greatnesse, that hee was seven times Consul, and preserved the Citie of Rome against the powerfull enemies, which assailed it.

The Cardinals favour, and greatnesse occasioned many Great, and Noble-men to make Factions, and Conspiracies against the King, and the Kingdome, and against the Cardinall himselfe: nay (if they are to be beleeved) they aymed onely at him, and he was the sole object of their envie, they would free (as they said) the King, and the Kingdome from a Tyrant: for, they imagined that he tyrannized the Kings will, and that hee oppressed the Kingdom.

Wee have spoken of the plot about putting the King into a Cloister 1626, we have said enough of the insurrection in Languedoc made by the Duke of
Orleans and the Duke of Montmorency 1632: we have said nothing as yet of that Grand Designe of the Duke of Beüillon, and of the Earle of Soissons, which get into France ayded with many Spaniards, and gave a great defeat unto the Kings Army: and had not the Cardinals care, vigilancie, and wisdome stopped their proceedings, France was like to become a prey unto the Spaniards. There hath been another plot of a newer stamp 1642, It was about bringing in tenne thousand Spaniards through Sedan to relieve the distressed, and oppressed French-men, and chiefly the Nobility of France, which was kept under by the Cardinall. Monsion do St. Marc, otherwise called Monsieur le Grand by reason of his dignity: was the chiefe contriver of it. Monsieur d • Fentrailles carried the Articles of agreement unto the King of Spaine, and s • brought them signed by his Catholick • Majesties hand unto Monsieur the
Duke of Orleans. The Cardinall discovered the plot: Monsieur do St. Marc was beheaded: and Mr. de Thou likewise: because the tender affection he bore unto Monsieur de St. Marc, as being his intimate friend, made him to keep secret a traiterous designe, from which he had discounselled the said Mr. St. Marc. but to conceale treason, is to be accessary unto it. The rest of the plot got out of the Kingdome. I have seen, and conversed with two of the chiefest for the space of foure, or five moneths together.

Such kinds of plots, and conspiracies did concerne the generality of France, though their pretence was particular, to wit, the putting downe of the Cardinall, and the destroying of his pretended tyrannicall government. Let us now relate some Conspiracies which were intended directly against the Cardinals person. One Alfeston borne in Chaalens was sent with two more from
Bruxelles be the perswasion of Father Chanteloube one of the Queen Mothers Councell; to kill him.

The plot being discovered Alfeston was broken upon the wheele by the sentence given against him in Metz. One Chavagnac was convicted for having attempted to poyson his Eminencie with a letter. One Bernard a Physitian condemned for coyning of mony, confessed that he had promised to poyson the Cardinall. Adrian Bouchard a Romish Priest, and Nicholas Gargan noted Magicians (as they say) were hired to doe the like. But they had a rope for their hire the nineteenth of Aprill 1634 in Paris. Their books were burned, and the cinders throwne into the ayre. It was said that a great French Duke did crosse the Sea 1641, because two men disguised in Hermits habits had conspired his death through his perswasion. But I heard them, that were the chiefest in his house, affirme the contrary. After so many
conspiracies against him, after the oppositions of so many strong enemies: to have him die a naturall death crowned with glory, and honour: as much in favour with his King, as any man could be: it seemeth to me somewhat like a miracle. The King visited him in his sicknesse: which was the greatest comfort that he could receive of any mortall man: seeing, that, having lived altogether for his King, he was to die neere him, and almost in his armes, as if God had so disposed of his life; that being ordained for the service of Lewis the thirteenth, and for the good of his Kingdome: almost the very last breath should be spent in his Majesties sight. He desired in his sicknesse, that he might live no longer, than he was able to doe the King, and the Kingdom of France service. Had heaven been pleased to hearken to his prayers: and to geant him his request: his life would have been of an equall lasting with the fates of the Kingdome of Prance.

He expired on a Thursday being the fourth of December, stilo navo, and the 14. stilo veteri, 1642. being about 58 yeeres old. Hee left nothing wanting unto the prosperity of the King, and of the Kingdome of France, but his owne person. Yet, the losse of so brave a man is in some measure recompenced by Cardinall Mazarin, who was the most intimate friend the Cardinall Richelieu had during his life, and one that knew the best part of his designes, and wanteth no wit to bring them to execution: and besides all this, hath given sufficient proofes of the zeale, and inclination hee hath for the good of France. So that French-men will never think that Richelieu is dead so long as Mazarin is alive. For, Richelieu's Genius remaineth still with Mazarin.

The Cardinall Richelieu was buried in the Colledge of Sorbenne, where he had caused his monument to be built, during his life. There could not be a fitter place to receive the body in which so wise, and
so learned a soule did inhabite: than that brave, and famous house of Learning.

Now: if you aske me of what Religion the Cardinall was, you shall pose me. The Romans say, that he was of their Religion: like enough so, for he caused warres to bee made against the Protestants: he hath written a book called the Christian Doctrine, for the instruction of the Romish Priests: and some things of controversie against the Protestants; Which for all that think that he was of their Religion: he was called the Cardinall Huguenot for a great while: he favoured the Protestants very much: and counselled the King even soone after the taking of Rochell, to protest publickly in the assembly of the most noted men in France, that hee would maintaine the Protestants in their Priviledges, and liberties. But, for my owne part, I believe that his religion, was best knowne unto himselfe; and, that it was as hard to dive into it, as into his policie. It is a
common thing to say, that Polititians greatest Religion, is to have none. Yet, it is not impossible to bee religiously politick. We may serve God, and our country likewise. I wish that France may never beare a worse Patriot than he was. That the Kings of France, may alwayes have as trusty, and as faithfull subjects. That the Reformed in France may never have a worse enemy; (all things rightly considered.)

It is seldome seen that the government of Clergy-men proveth so successefull unto their Kings, and Kingdomes; as that of Cardinall Richelieu did. For; they doe seek oftentimes too much to exalt themselves, and their tribe: and by those meanes overthrow themselves, their adherents, and the Kingdomes, or republicks, wherein they live. For: the overgreat pride, and state of the Clergy is apt to breed a kind of heart-burning amongst the Nobility and Gentry: nay amongst some of their owne profession, and amongst
the Commonalty. So that: they conspire many times altogether the ruine, and the down-fall of the pride of such men: which should rather gaine love, and respect by their humble conversation: then cause envie by their vain, and stately pompe. If the Clergy mount up their Canons against the Laiety: They will plant their Ordnance against them. If Justinian striveth to get the upper hand: William the Conqueror will so justle with him, that he will goe neer to thrust him out. Therefore, it is best for him to bee contented with the honour, and place, which is allowed, and assigned unto him: and not to desire to ascend any higher. Some say, that the Cardinall called the now Bishop of Canterbury, his Ape. I cannot believe that his Eminency was so uncivill, as to speak so irreverently of his Grace. Peradventure he called him his Imitator: and I would he had imitated him indeed. Kingdomes are compared unto ships, their Kings to
Pilots. States-men, upon which they repose the government of the ship, may be called their Deputy Pilots, and in a manner the Masters mates. The Cardinall governed France intrusted to him, in all tempests risen against it without either shipwrack or losse: left it enjoying a good calme in the Haven. May it please God to let no tempest arise after the death of the Masters mate, and of the Master himselfe, that cast that brave ship of France upon some rock, or bank. A French man made two verses in Latin, and French by a kind of a propheticall spirit of the Kingdom of France compared with a ship, and of the Cardinall being the Pilot of it, I will end with them.

q.l: Te duce sulcabit fluctus, portum{que} tenebit:
Va navire ne craint point, ton Pilote est un Dieu,
Jamais Anchre ne fut en un plus Richelieu
